Content-Type: text/plain;

Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

I'm picking apart the Windows NEAT code I have, and mulling over some of
the threads from the group, and I have some questions. 

innovation #s vs ID #s: are they the same thing? I see some code
readability to using unique id numbers, but I don't understand what
innovation #s are for. I was reading postings about remembering all the
innovations. what benifit does this have?

genotype vs phenotype: I know there has been a lot of talk and interest
in modular structures, where the phenotype is not a direct mapping of
the genotype, but if ( as in with NEAT ) the phenotype IS a direct map,
wouldn't it be simpler not to seperate the two? As I understand it, the
idea is to build networks that can be mutated and crossed with other
networks. What benifit does the genotype/phenotype distinction provide?

species: can speciation be summarized as method of evolving multiple
populations simultaniously, or is there too much mixing between species?
I havn't read too deep into the speciation code. I don't really grasp
what it's supposed to accomplish. Windows NEAT essentially seems to use
the species class as a simple container with accessors. Is that it?

long, lengthy, and otherwise wordy replies would be great.
thanks,
chad

I'm picking apart the Windows NEAT code I have, and mulling over some of the threads from the group, and I have some questions. <br>
<br>
innovation #s vs ID #s: are they the same thing? I see some code readability to using unique id numbers, but I don't understand what innovation #s are for. I was reading postings about remembering all the innovations. what benifit does this have?<br>
<br>
genotype vs phenotype: I know there has been a lot of talk and interest in modular structures, where the phenotype is not a direct mapping of the genotype, but if ( as in with NEAT ) the phenotype IS a direct map, wouldn't it be simpler not to seperate the two? As I understand it, the idea is to build networks that can be mutated and crossed with other networks. What benifit does the genotype/phenotype distinction provide?<br>
<br>
species: can speciation be summarized as method of evolving multiple populations simultaniously, or is there too much mixing between species? I havn't read too deep into the speciation code. I don't really grasp what it's supposed to accomplish. Windows NEAT essentially seems to use the species class as a simple container with accessors. Is that it?<br>
<br>
long, lengthy, and otherwise wordy replies would be great.<br>
thanks,<br>
chad 
</BODY></HTML>
